column1: Moses Lake is a city in Grant County
column3: United States. The population was 20
column4: 366 as of the 2010 census.  Moses Lake is the largest city in Grant County. The city anchors the Moses Lake Micropolitan area
column5: which includes all of Grant County and is part of the Moses Lake-Othello combined statistical area.

column3: is made up of three main arms over 18 miles (29 km) long and up to one mile (1.6 km) wide. It is the largest natural body of fresh water in Grant County and has over 120 miles (190 km) of shoreline covering 6
column4: 500 acres (2
column5: 600 ha). Before it was dammed in the early 1900s and then incorporated into the Columbia Basin Project
column6: Moses Lake was a smaller shallow lake. To the south of the town is the Potholes Reservoir and the Columbia National Wildlife Refuge that has a number of seep lakes and vast amounts of migratory birds and other fauna natural to the area.

column1: Before the construction of Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River in 1941 and Moses Lake Army Air Base in 1942 the area was largely barren. Native Americans knew the area as Houaph
column2: which meant willow. Chief Moses was leader of the Sinkiuse tribe from 1859 to 1899
column3: and was forced to negotiate with white settlers who began to settle in the area in the 1880s. Under pressure from the government
column4: Chief Moses traded the Columbia Basin land for a reservation that stretched from Lake Chelan north to the Canada–US border. The government later traded again for what is now the Colville Indian Reservation.

column1: The new settlers named the lake in honor of Chief Moses. The city was originally named Neppel
column2: after a town in Germany where one of the original settlers had lived. The first settlers established fisheries and farms — some of the first exported items were carp
column3: jackrabbits and fruit — but irrigation attempts failed and settlers left at about the same rate as they came. When the town was incorporated and renamed Moses Lake in 1938
column4: the population was estimated at 302 people.The arrival of the air base in 1942 and irrigation water pumped from Grand Coulee Dam in 1955 offered newcomers a reason and a way to settle in an area that previously had little to offer other than good fishing and a place to water sheep and cattle. Moses Lake was quickly transformed into a hub for a vast region where transportation
column5: agriculture and recreation came together.The air base was built to train World War II pilots to fly the P-38 Lightning and B-17 Flying Fortress
column6: two planes that were essential to the war effort. The base was closed after the war ended
column7: but reopened in 1948 as a U.S. Air Force base and test area for Boeing's B-47 Stratojet and B-50 Superfortress.

column1: The B-47 tests led to development of modern commercial jetliners still used today. Fighter jets were stationed there to protect Grand Coulee Dam to the north and the Hanford site to the south. Boeing still uses the airport as a test and evaluation facility for its aircraft. Japan Airlines used the airport as a training area from November 1968 until March 2009. The old air base is now owned by the Port of Moses Lake and is home to Grant County International Airport
column2: Big Bend Community College and several businesses.

column3: had developed new methods to irrigate water from the lake and from the Columbia River and began planting expansive irrigated acreage. When the Columbia Basin Project was completed in the mid-1950s
column4: farms expanded by thousands of acres

column1: Moses Lake has a dry climate
column2: and is classed as a semi-arid climate. It is warm during summer
column3: when temperatures tend to be in the 80s (°F) and somewhat cold during winter
column4: when temperatures tend to be in the 30s (°F). The warmest month is July
column5: with an average maximum temperature of 88.20 °F (31.22 °C). The coldest month is January
column6: with an average minimum temperature of 21.70 °F (−5.72 °C).

column1: Temperature variations between night and day are greater during summer (27 °F (−3 °C))
The annual average precipitation at Moses Lake is 7.69 inches (195 mm). Although rainfall is fairly evenly distributed throughout the year
column2: it is not unusual in mid-summer for a month or six weeks to pass without any measurable rainfall. The wettest month is December with an average rainfall of 1.19 inch (30 mm).

column1: Moses Lake's historic economic base has been agriculture
column2: but now includes considerable manufacturing and technology. Several companies have moved to the area
column3: including REC Silicon (one of the world's largest manufacturers of polysilicon
column4: used in solar panels). Moses Lake has also attracted some alternative fuel companies
column5: such as Washington Ethanol & Washington Biodiesel.

column2: in partnership with the SGL Group
column3: began construction in July 2010 on a $100 million carbon-fiber manufacturing plant. The plant was designed to produce 300 tons of carbon fiber per year from a single production building
column4: and began operations in 2011. In 2013
column5: ground was broken for a second 300-ton building
column6: bringing projected production to 600 tons per year. In 2014
column7: a third 300-ton building was started. When the third building is completed
column8: SGL Moses Lake will be the largest producer of carbon fiber in the world. Mitsubishi in 2016 announced that the company would use the port of Moses Lake for its new regional jet (MRJ) FAA flight testing. The testing will be completed by the end of 2018.

column1: Other major corporations that have facilities in (or are based in) Moses Lake include:
Moses Lake is bisected by two major highways that bypass the city center: Interstate 90 and State Route 17. State Route 171 and Interstate 90 Business serve the city's downtown
The Columbia Basin Railroad is headquartered in Moses Lake and operates the city's railroad. It is the busiest shortline railroad in Eastern Washington.During the 1990s
column2: a high-speed rail line between Seattle and Moses Lake was proposed
column3: primarily to use Grant County International Airport as a satellite airport for the Seattle metropolitan area.As of 2020
column4: the rail has been closed.

column1: Moses Lake and Grant County are served by the Grant Transit Authority
column2: which runs several bus routes within the city and intercity bus service to nearby Ephrata and other towns.

Moses Lake Sand Dunes are open year-round to 4x4 and ORV enthusiasts. The Sand Dunes bring people from all over the world to play in the sand.
Moses Lake has one sister city
column2: according to the Washington State Lt. Governor's list of Washington Sister Cities:
JapanMoses Lake has a long history with its sister city; Yonezawa
column3: Japan. The two cities have been exchanging students every summer for over 20 years. There is a street named after Yonezawa in Moses Lake and a street named after Moses Lake in Yonezawa. In 2019
column4: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints announced plans to build the Moses Lake Washington Temple on Yonezawa Boulevard between Division Street and Road K NE.
